repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #6992 (and a few other variations of the same thing)

------------------------------------------------------------

Includes https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/7001 so might be worth merging that first

comment_data.body: I'm a little wary here of how much `h_code_start`->`h_code_main` might change the order... we'll see
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -282,31 +283,35 @@ def h_entries(entries, api=0, pxd=0):
             h_guard = self.api_name(Naming.h_guard_prefix, env)
             h_code_start.put_h_guard(h_guard)
             h_code_start.putln("")
+            self._put_setup_code(h_code_start, "InitLimitedAPI")
             h_code_start.putln('#include "Python.h"')
-            self.generate_type_header_code(h_types, h_code_start)
+            self.generate_type_header_code(h_types, h_code_main)

comment_data.body: Isn't this too general? I understand that we need to declare any supertypes, but why do we need to include all subtypes when a type is used? Shouldn't we know which subtypes are used (via `entry.used`) and only include the utility code for those (and their supertypes)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1791,6 +1791,9 @@ def use_entry_utility_code(self, entry):
             self.utility_code_list.append(entry.utility_code)
         if entry.utility_code_definition:
             self.utility_code_list.append(entry.utility_code_definition)
+        for tp in PyrexTypes.get_all_subtypes(entry.type):
+            if hasattr(tp, "entry") and tp.entry is not entry:
+                self.use_entry_utility_code(tp.entry)

comment_data.body:
Shouldn't this have a `//@requires: …Decl`? I understand that both are included explicitly, but the code sections have a clear dependency that is not reflected in their definition. And maybe then it wouldn't be necessary any more to include both explicitly? And, also maybe, the `…Usage` suffix could disappear again?
(The same comment applies to `PyMutex` below.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,18 @@
-////////////////////// PyThreadTypeLock.proto //////////
+////////////////////// PyThreadTypeLockDecl.proto //////////
 //@proto_block: utility_code_proto_before_types
 
 // This lock type always uses PyThread_type_lock. The main reason
 // to use it is if you are using the Limited API and want to
 // share locks between modules.
 
+#ifndef __PYX_HAVE_PYX_THREAD_TYPE_LOCK_DECL
+#define __PYX_HAVE_PYX_THREAD_TYPE_LOCK_DECL
 #define __Pyx_Locks_PyThreadTypeLock PyThread_type_lock
 #define __Pyx_Locks_PyThreadTypeLock_DECL NULL
+#endif
+
+////////////////////// PyThreadTypeLockUsage.proto //////////////////
+

comment_data.body: I guess this duplication is only because the whole method is duplicated in `Symtab.py`, which shouldn't be the case.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2380,6 +2380,10 @@ def use_entry_utility_code(self, entry):
             self.use_utility_code(entry.utility_code)
         if entry.utility_code_definition:
             self.use_utility_code(entry.utility_code_definition)
+        from . import PyrexTypes
+        for tp in PyrexTypes.get_all_subtypes(entry.type):
+            if hasattr(tp, "entry") and tp.entry is not entry:
+                self.use_entry_utility_code(tp.entry)

comment_data.body:
"subtypes" isn't inheritance in this context. It's things like the return types and argument types of a function type.

`entry.used` seems (fairly) reliable for variable entries but completely unset for type entries unfortunately.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1791,6 +1791,9 @@ def use_entry_utility_code(self, entry):
             self.utility_code_list.append(entry.utility_code)
         if entry.utility_code_definition:
             self.utility_code_list.append(entry.utility_code_definition)
+        for tp in PyrexTypes.get_all_subtypes(entry.type):
+            if hasattr(tp, "entry") and tp.entry is not entry:
+                self.use_entry_utility_code(tp.entry)

comment_data.body: Yeah - agree that there's a dependency so I'll add it. Don't think it avoids using `...Decl` implicitly though (it might for pyx files, but for the headers and pxd includes it definitely doesn't because that's what doesn't work now)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,18 @@
-////////////////////// PyThreadTypeLock.proto //////////
+////////////////////// PyThreadTypeLockDecl.proto //////////
 //@proto_block: utility_code_proto_before_types
 
 // This lock type always uses PyThread_type_lock. The main reason
 // to use it is if you are using the Limited API and want to
 // share locks between modules.
 
+#ifndef __PYX_HAVE_PYX_THREAD_TYPE_LOCK_DECL
+#define __PYX_HAVE_PYX_THREAD_TYPE_LOCK_DECL
 #define __Pyx_Locks_PyThreadTypeLock PyThread_type_lock
 #define __Pyx_Locks_PyThreadTypeLock_DECL NULL
+#endif
+
+////////////////////// PyThreadTypeLockUsage.proto //////////////////
+

@@ -2380,6 +2380,10 @@ def use_entry_utility_code(self, entry):
             self.use_utility_code(entry.utility_code)
         if entry.utility_code_definition:
             self.use_utility_code(entry.utility_code_definition)
+        from . import PyrexTypes
+        for tp in PyrexTypes.get_all_subtypes(entry.type):
+            if hasattr(tp, "entry") and tp.entry is not entry:
+                self.use_entry_utility_code(tp.entry)

comment_data.body: Ok, sorry, my mistake then. A case of "good naming is hard", I guess - one would never think of all possible contexts.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1791,6 +1791,9 @@ def use_entry_utility_code(self, entry):
             self.utility_code_list.append(entry.utility_code)
         if entry.utility_code_definition:
             self.utility_code_list.append(entry.utility_code_definition)
+        for tp in PyrexTypes.get_all_subtypes(entry.type):
+            if hasattr(tp, "entry") and tp.entry is not entry:
+                self.use_entry_utility_code(tp.entry)

comment_data.body:
This might be more readable where it's used:
```suggestion
def _type_to_itself(tp):
```

```suggestion
        if type(other) is not type(self):
            return NotImplemented
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5022,6 +5023,14 @@ def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
     def create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
         return False
 
+    def __eq__(self, other):
+        if type(other) != type(self):
+            return False

commit.message:
Add Limited API macros into api/public headers

This is mainly just preparation for sorting out pymutex in
public headers (since I think we'll want to use the Limited API
macros to support it).

However - it also simplifies the import and export code slightly
and is one less thing to remember to do differently in this
header code.

Added a test since it seemed pretty untested.
Fix Limited API, code style; skip PyPy

Revert "Add Limited API macros into api/public headers"

This reverts commit 9201182b99a709cb65e513480316c13b1aeea362.

title: Generate utility code for public/api/cimported pymutex types
